On women's traditional mourning role in Mediterranean societies, see ibid

Strocchia pointed out a sumptuary legislation double standard whereby a large group of kin could wear "deep mourning" for male relatives, but only a woman's children and one other female relative might do the same. The end result of such legislation meant women both received fewer post-mortem honors, and that live women had fewer opportunities to express family honor through mourning

title: According to his appendix list of dogaresse, Staley seemed to have understood dogaressa to mean any wife of any man who would one day become doge, whether she was still living or not.
